The College Board runs the game, and there is an intimate, mutual dependency between them and the colleges,” he said. “They are selling class and that’s a good business to be in. People are terrified of falling out of the middle class. Basically, your job as a parent is to make sure your kids don’t fall out of the middle class.”

post_text: This article relates to our Town hall meeting last year on the Motorola TIF plan. Worth reading...
shared_text:
DAILYHERALD.COM
"We want it to feel urban, dense and walkable." Schaumburg OKs Motorola campus plan.

Eric Peterson shared a link to the group: Everything Palatine.
April 11, 2018 at 9:03 AM ·

Schaumburg officials have long favored a dense, urban redevelopment of the former Motorola Solutions campus, but trustees Tuesday approved a new zoning district and design guidelines that officially enable that vision and allow individual proposals that have been waiting in the wings to move forward with more confidence. But the Palatine Park District, which has jurisdiction over part of the site, expressed reservations about both the financial impact on local governments as well as the amount of open space the plan calls for.

post_text:
COMMUNITY EDUCATION EVENT: SCHOOL SAFETY

As part of an ongoing commitment to community information and partnerships, personnel from District 15, District 211 and the Palatine Police Department will present a community education session on the topic of school safety.

The event will be held Thursday, April 12 from 7-8:30 p.m. in the Palatine High School Auditorium (1111 N. Rohlwing Road, Palatine). Administrators from High School District 211 and CCSD15, along with representatives from the Palatine Police Department will focus on school and police coordination, and best practices to maintain safety in our schools.

District 211 and the Hoffman Estates and Schaumburg Police Departments will hold a similar session on Wednesday, April 11 at Hoffman Estates High School from 7-8:30 p.m.

The community education sessions are open to the public.

post_text:
District 15 is developing a strategic plan this spring to provide clear direction and vision for the Board of Education and administration over the next several years.

Community input will determine the foundation of the strategic plan: The aspirational values for the school district and our students. Aspirational values are the organizational qualities for which a school district wants to be known or the individual attributes we believe characterize a successful student.

Please provide your feedback through this five-minute online survey. Responses will be accepted through Sunday, March 11.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdAKjuWagkPTLoB-
dfvSmzda2cAH3YalxzgmL3j48TSiNLceA/viewform

post_text:
Today's D15 E-Newsletter included the following survey information. In case you don't get the newsletter, here is the info: How does your school rank according to the Illinois 5Essentials questionnaire? This is your opportunity to evaluate your school according to five areas, including but not limited to instructional climate, homework policies and quality of facilities. Fill out your 5Essentials online survey through Jan. 18.

The results from this survey will become part of each school's public Illinois School Report Card. The data is also used periodically by media outlets as part of national and state school rankings.

PLEASE NOTE: District 15 is located in Cook County, so please select "Cook" from the county drop-down list.
++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
FYI, the survey includes an option for parents, teachers and students to respond, but not for D15 citizens as a whole.

post_text:
BOE Nov 8 meeting update on Motorola TIF topic....
The BOE meeting video link is up at https://youtu.be/w4XFPkifqzw

At the 1:26:04 approx point, Supt. Thompson discusses some ideas for discussion with the Village Manager at Schaumburg.
In short, he mentioned:
1. Impact fees
2. Setting aside TIF money to pay D15 if kids live in the residential area and attend D15 schools-that annual cost is estimated currently at about $13,000/student/year
3. Donating land in the TIF area for a possible school to be constructed
4. Redesigning the concept plan to move the majority of homes into the D54 boundaries- apparently D54 have 28 buildings and in the last few years their enrollment has shrunk by 3,000 to approx. 14,0000.

The Village Board meets next as per below:
TOWNSHIP OF SCHAUMBURG
1 Illinois Boulevard, Hoffman Estates, IL 60169
COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE
Upper Level – Board Room
AGENDA
7:00 p.m. Thursday November 9th, 2017

Public Comment is item 1- limit = 3 minutes per person.
FYI

post_text:
The regular monthly Board meeting on Wed Oct 12 will be preceded by a special meeting at 6:30pm. According to the special meeting minutes, the meeting is essentially to go into Executive Session to discuss "Collective negotiating matters between the District and its employees or their representatives, or deliberations concerning salary schedules for one or more classes of employees."

Prior to going into Executive Session, there is an agenda item where Citizens (may) Address the Board.

The regular meeting starts at 7:00pm.

post_text: I will ask the district for a response
shared_text:
Lisa Marth-Brock‎OurD15Voice
June 2, 2017 at 10:00 PM ·

The last day of school I learned that all District 15 Librarians will split their time between 2 schools rotating 2 days one week, 3 the next. This may have come up in the flurry of changes and somehow I missed this....can you share the rationale and if there are any other significant changes anticipated for the 2017-2018 school year?

post_text:
Full Day Kindergarten - Is it Worth It?

Full day Kindergarten can be very desirable parents with young children. Do you think the cost to the district is worth the investment? Should taxpayers fund the expansion? Should the onus fall on parents? Should there be a sliding scale based on income? Does D15 need to offer full-day K in order to be a desirable place to live?

The following Chicago Tribune article discusses the circumstances and challenges of offering full-day Kindergarten in suburban Chicago. More links and statistics are available in the comments section.

The D15 Community Engagement Committee is soliciting feedback on the many topics that are important to all citizen groups. Articles and information do not reflect the opinions of the committee and are meant to be a starting point for discussion. Please feel free to join past conversations as they are meant to be ongoing.

http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/libertyville/news/ct-all-day-kindergarten-deerfield-met-20150209-story.html

post_text:
Smaller class sizes are something we all prefer, but is the cost worth the benefit? Do you think smaller class sizes should be aimed at certain grade levels, all grades, or not at all? This article provides information about the pros and cons of smaller class sizes. The D15 Community Engagement Committee does not endorse the opinions expressed in the article; it is meant to be a resource to help start an informed, ongoing discussion on one of the issues facing the district. More topics will be posted in coming weeks.
https://www.publicschoolreview.com/blog/smaller-class-sizes-pros-and-cons

Dear District 15 Stakeholder,

The District 15 Community Engagement Committee is seeking input from stakeholders.

We are gathering information which will assist the Board of Education and District administration in setting the priorities for its term ahead.

Please take a moment to respond to our two-question survey.

The survey will be open through Friday, April 28.

post_text:
Help us connect!

The D15 Community Engagement Committee had another productive meeting last night. We are formulating next steps for reaching out to a wide range of community-based groups, and are looking for assistance identifying potential audiences.

Are you part of a PTA, service organization, homeowner's association, neighbor group, etc.?

Please let us know if you have ideas on community groups we should contact.

post_text:
The Community Engagement Committee is looking for some help. We're looking for contacts into local Homeowner groups so we can reach deeper into the community. If you know the current contact for a Palatine area (CCSD15) homeowner group (or condo association, or apartment complex) please enter it here.

The Committee is committed to reaching out to all the members of the District 15 community: parents, retirees, business owners, long-time residents, and new families.
If you have questions about this survey, please feel free to reach out to Rob Coleman @ roberthcoleman.il@gmail.com

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdmoYpHhps-5b6E4UiOGj0kGI_DrFSrTZgQF90JJhljTJ-pfg/viewform?c=0&w=1

post_text: Como comite, estamos a cargo de ampliar la comunicación en el D15 entre el consejo escolar y la comunidad. Nosotros guiaremos al Distrito en el diseño de un proceso para involucrar a los miembros de la comunidad en explorar problemas críticos en las escuelas del D15. Por ejemplo: ofertas de programas, rendimiento académico, y estrategias para disminuir la diferencia de rendimiento académico y satisfacer las necesidades de los estudiantes"en riesgo", planeación fiscal, sobrecupo escolar, y estructuras y configuraciones escolares efectivas... y temas importantes para USTED!
text: Como comite, estamos a cargo de ampliar la comunicación en el D15 entre el consejo escolar y la comunidad. Nosotros guiaremos al Distrito en el diseño de un proceso para involucrar a los miembros de la comunidad en explorar problemas críticos en las escuelas del D15. Por ejemplo: ofertas de programas, rendimiento académico, y estrategias para disminuir la diferencia de rendimiento académico y satisfacer las necesidades de los estudiantes"en riesgo", planeación fiscal, sobrecupo escolar, y estructuras y configuraciones escolares efectivas... y temas importantes para USTED!
